required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Tension Versus no Tension With Foley Bulb Induction
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomized Comparison of Tension Versus no Tension With Foley Transcervical Catheters for Pre-induction Cervical Ripening

brief_summary.textblock: To compare the application of tension versus no tension in Foley transcervical catheters for pre-induction cervical ripening.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients who are scheduled to undergo labor induction will be offered inclusion in the study which will attempt to determine if placing tension on the foley ballon will shorten the interval between induction initiation and delivery.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Will measure length of time from beginning of induction with the foley balloon until delivery

clinical_study.condition: Induction of Labor Affected Fetus / Newborn

arm_group.description: foley balloon will be placed on tension and taped to thigh at 10 cm. Misoprostil will be placed in posterior vaginal vault.
The foley balloon will be loosely taped without tension to the patient's thigh. Misoprostil will be placed in the posterior vaginal vault.

intervention.description: Tension applied to catheter and taped firmly to leg.
Foley balloon will be taped loosely to the leg and not placed on tension. All other care will remain the same

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Nulliparas with singleton live intrauterine pregnancies undergoing labor induction at Kapiolani Medical Center for Women and Children.
- Cephalic presentation
- Intact fetal membranes
- Bishop score less than or equal to 6
- Age greater than or equal to 18 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Multiparas
- Multiple gestation
- Previous uterine/cervical surgery
- Ruptured fetal membranes
- Fetal malpresentation
- Any contraindication to vaginal delivery at time of admission

facility.name: Kapiolani Medical Center for Women and Children
